question: Question_A_04
statement:
Circle the \emph{one} correct answer below. A linear system of two
equations in three unknowns has

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\textbf{(a)} always a unique solution.

\textbf{(b)} either a unique solution or no solutions.

\textbf{(c)} either a unique solution or an infinite number of
solutions.

\textbf{(d)} either no solutions or an infinite number of solutions.

\textbf{(e)} either a unique solution or exactly two distinct solutions.
\end{description}
sols:
With two equations (rows in the matrix), there can be at most 2 pivots
and thus there is at least one free variable. A free variable implies
that there are an infinite number of solutions provided that the right
hand side vector vanishes wherever there is a row of zeros, otherwise a
solution does not exist. Therefore, we either have at least one valid
free variable which implies that there are an infinite number of
solutions or the right hand side vector does not vanish whenever there
is a row of zeros. Therefore we either have no solutions or an infinite
number of solutions when a linear system has 2 equations with three
unknowns. Therefore, the correct option is
(d).\\\\\textbf{Advanced}:\\Recall that the
\href{Wikipedia:Rank_(linear_algebra)}{rank} (\emph{r}) of a matrix
defines the number of linearly independent rows or columns of a matrix
or linear system and recall that for any matrix \emph{A} size \emph{m}
by \emph{n} that,\\\begin{align*}r\leq\min(n,m).\end{align*} For this example we have
\emph{m}=2 and \emph{n}=3 and so \emph{r} $\leq$ 2. The dimension of the
nullspace is \emph{n}-\emph{r} and in this case it is at least 1 which
implies that there are non-trivial solutions to''A\textbf{x} ''=
\textbf{0} and in fact there are an infinite number of them. A solution
to''A\textbf{x} ''= \textbf{\emph{b}} exists as long as \textbf{''b}''
is spanned by the column space of \emph{A}. If this is true then''A\textbf{x} ''= \textbf{\emph{b}} has a particular solution along with
the infinite set of solutions belonging to the nullspace and therefore
overall there are an infinite number of solutions. However, if
\textbf{\emph{b}} is \textbf{not} spanned by the column space of
\emph{A} then there are no solutions to''A\textbf{x} ''=
\textbf{\emph{b}}. Therefore, we conclude that a linear system with 2
equations in 3 unknowns has (d) either no solutions or an infinite
number of solutions.
hints:
Consider how many pivots and free variables there are with 3 unknowns
and two equations.
